         <p id=\"close-icon-description\" class=\"offscreen-hidden\">\n                Click here to close this overlay, or press the \"Escape\" key on your keyboard.\n            </p>\n            <form id=\"alertsForm\" class=\"overlay-panel__form\" method=\"post\" action=\"\" role=\"form\" aria-labelledby=\"alerts-box-title\">\n                <div class=\"overlay-panel__header\">\n                    <div class=\"overlay-panel__logo\"></div>\n                    <span id=\"alerts-box-title\" class=\"replica-h2\">Corridor alerts</span>\n                    <p id=\"alerts-box-desc\">\n                        Receive alerts on all new research papers in American Astronomical Society\n                        (<span class=\"abbr__aas\">A&nbsp;A&nbsp;S&nbsp;</span>) journals as soon as they are published.\n                        Select your desired journals and corridors below. You will need to select a minimum of one corridor.\n                    </p>\n                </div>\n                <div class=\"overlay-panel__container\">\n                    <div class=\"overlay-panel__col\">\n                        <fieldset id=\"alerts-corridors-list\">\n                            <legend id=\"corridors-title\" class=\"overlay-panel__heading replica-h3 mb-05\">Corridors</legend>\n                        </fieldset>\n                    </div>\n                    <div class=\"overlay-panel__col\">\n                        <fieldset id=\"alerts-journals-list\">\n                            <legend id=\"journals-title\" class=\"overlay-panel__heading replica-h3 mb-05\">Journals</legend>\n                        </fieldset>\n                    </div>\n                    <div class=\"boxout-bg-blue-light overlay-panel__extra-info\">\n                        <p>\n                            Please note, The Astrophysical Journal Letters (ApJL) and Research Notes of the AAS (RNAAS)\n                            do not currently use the corridors.\n                        </p>\n                    </div>\n                </div>\n                <div class=\"overlay-panel__footer\">\n                    <div class=\"overlay-panel__inner-footer\">\n                        <input id=\"update-alerts\" type=\"submit\" value=\"Create alert\" class=\"btn btn-default overlay-panel__btn\" role=\"button\">\n                        <div class=\"icon-spinner spinner overlay-panel__loading\"></div>\n                    </div>\n                </div>\n            </form>\n        </div>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- End TOC Subjects Popup -->\n            <p class=\"mb-0\"><a class=\"wd-jnl-email-alert jnl-email-alert--corridors-info\" href=\"https://journals.aas.org/corridors.html\"\n               target=\"_blank\" title=\"Find out more about AAS corridors.\">\n                What are corridors? <span class=\"icon-newtab\">\n            </a></p>\n        </div>\n\n    <!-- End Email Alert -->\n<!-- End Email Alert --><!-- Start Citation Alert Link -->\n                        <p>\n<div class=\"jnl-notifications-wrapper\">\n    <a class=\"wd-jnl-email-alert\" href=\"https://myiopscience.iop.org/signin?origin=a0&return=https%3A%2F%2Fiopscience.iop.org%2Fmyiopscience%2Falerts%2Fsubscribe%3FarticleID%3D0004-637X%2F864%2F1%2F91\"><span\n            class=\"icon-alarm icon-alarm--jhp\"></span>Create citation alert</a>\n</div><!-- End Citation Alert Link -->\n                    </div>\n\t\t</div>\n    </div>\n    <!-- Article information ends -->\n<!-- Start Info top-->\n    <!-- end Info top --><div class=\"article-content\">\n\t<span id=\"articleId\" class=\"hide\">0004-637X/864/1/91</span>\n<!-- Start Abstract -->\n    <h2 id=\"artAbst\" class=\"collapse-blocked\">Abstract</h2>\n        <!-- Start article video abstract -->\n\t<!-- End article video abstract -->\n\t<div class=\"article-text wd-jnl-art-abstract cf\" itemprop=\"description\">\n             <P>We propose a new strategy of finding strongly lensed supernovae (SNe) by monitoring known galaxy-scale strong-lens systems. Strongly lensed SNe are potentially powerful tools for the study of cosmology, galaxy evolution, and stellar populations, but they are extremely rare. By targeting known strongly lensed star-forming galaxies, our strategy significantly boosts the detection efficiency for lensed SNe compared to a blind search. As a reference sample, we compile the 128 galaxy\u2013galaxy strong-lens systems from the Sloan Lens ACS Survey (SLACS), the SLACS for the Masses Survey, and the Baryon Oscillation Spectroscopic Survey Emission-Line Lens Survey. Within this sample, we estimate the rates of strongly lensed Type Ia SN (SNIa) and core-collapse SN (CCSN) to be 1.23\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.12 and 10.4\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01.1 events per year, respectively. The lensed SN images are expected to be widely separated with a median separation of 2 arcsec. Assuming a conservative fiducial lensing magnification factor of 5 for the most highly magnified SN image, we forecast that a monitoring program with a single-visit depth of 24.7 mag (5<I>\u03c3</I> point source, <I>r</I> band) and a cadence of 5 days can detect 0.49 strongly lensed SNIa event and 2.1 strongly lensed CCSN events per year within this sample. Our proposed targeted-search strategy is particularly useful for prompt and efficient identifications and follow-up observations of strongly lensed SN candidates. It also allows telescopes with small fields of view and limited time to efficiently discover strongly lensed SNe with a pencil-beam scanning strategy.</P> </div>\n    <!-- End abstract -->\n<!-- Start Export citation and abstract tools -->\n\t<p>\n\t\t<small>Export citation and abstract</small>\n\t\t<span class=\"btn-multi-block\">\n\t\t\t<a href=\"/export?articleId=0004-637X/864/1/91&doi=10.3847/1538-4357/aad5ea&exportFormat=iopexport_bib&exportType=abs&navsubmit=Export+abstract\" class=\"btn btn-primary wd-btn-cit-abs-bib\" title=\"Export BibTex\">BibTeX</a>\n\t\t\t<a href=\"/export?articleId=0004-637X/864/1/91&doi=10.3847/1538-4357/aad5ea&exportFormat=iopexport_ris&exportType=abs&navsubmit=Export+abstract\" class=\"btn btn-primary wd-btn-cit-abs-ris\" title=\"Export RIS\">RIS</a>\n\t\t</span>\n\t</p>\n<!-- End Export citation and abstract tools -->\n<!-- Start AAS Related Links -->\n<div class=\"reveal-container reveal-closed reveal-plus-icon bdt-1 mt-2 mb-2 wd-jnl-art-article-aas-related-links\">\n  <div class=\"replica-h3 mt-0\">\n    <a href=\"#\" class=\"reveal-trigger\" data-reveal-label-alt=\"Hide related links\">Related links</a>\n  </div>\n  <div class=\"reveal-content\">\n    <div class=\"article-meta\"> \n      <ul>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2018ApJ...864...91S\" target=\"_blank\">NASA ADS Record <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://nedwww.ipac.caltech.edu/cgi-bin/nph-objsearch?refcode=2018ApJ...864...91S&search_type=Search \" target=\"_blank\">NED Objects <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-ref?querymethod=bib&simbo=on&bibcode=2018ApJ...864...91S\" target=\"_blank\">Simbad Objects <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"/journal/0004-637X/page/About%20Related%20Links\" target=\"_blank\">About Related Links</a></li>\n      \t</ul>\n    </div>\n  </div>\n</div>\n<!-- Start info bottom -->\n    <!-- End info bottom -->\n<!-- Start article full text -->\n\t<div xmlns:book=\"http://api.iop.org/Book/1.0/\" itemprop=\"articleBody\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-full-text article-text\">\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjaad5eas1\" name=\"apjaad5eas1\">1.\u00a0Introduction</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>Supernovae (SNe) are powerful tools for understanding fundamental physics from cosmology to nucleosynthesis. Most prominently for cosmology, the \"standard-candle\" nature of Type Ia SN (SNIa) was used to discover the accelerating expansion of the universe (e.g., Riess et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib140\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib140\">1998</a>; Schmidt et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib147\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib147\">1998</a>; Perlmutter et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib130\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib130\">1999</a>). By calibrating against distance-independent observables, Type II SNe have also been used for cosmological studies (e.g., Nugent et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib123\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib123\">2006</a>; Jones et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib79\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib79\">2009</a>; Kasen &amp; Woosley <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib82\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib82\">2009</a>; Poznanski et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib132\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib132\">2009</a>; Olivares et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib127\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib127\">2010</a>; de Jaeger et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib37\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib37\">2017)</a>, although the dispersion in the distance inferred from Type II SNe (~10%) is a factor of ~2 larger than that from SNe Ia (e.g., Betoule et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib12\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib12\">2014</a>; Rubin &amp; Hayden <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib142\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib142\">2016</a>). Of particular interest for astrophysics, observations of the pre- or early explosion phases of an SN can constrain the properties of its progenitor, and by extension probe the physics of late-stage stellar evolution (e.g., Soderberg et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib157\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib157\">2008</a>; Li et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib95\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib95\">2011a</a>; Nugent et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib124\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib124\">2011</a>; Dilday et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib40\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib40\">2012</a>; Wang et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib187\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib187\">2013</a>; McCully et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib108\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib108\">2014</a>; Foley et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib51\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib51\">2015</a>; Ganot et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib56\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib56\">2016</a>; Tornamb\u00e9 et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib177\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib177\">2018</a>).</p><p>The strong gravitational lensing effect furnishes another powerful tool for cosmology. From relative delays in the arrival times of multiple images, the Hubble constant can be measured for a given lensing mass model (e.g., Impey et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib75\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib75\">1998</a>; Witt et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib189\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib189\">2000</a>; Treu &amp; Koopmans <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib181\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib181\">2002</a>; Koopmans et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib90\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib90\">2003</a>; Suyu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib170\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib170\">2010</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib169\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib169\">2013</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib171\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib171\">2014</a>; Bonvin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib21\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib21\">2017</a>; Wong et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib191\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib191\">2017</a>). This so-called \"time-delay cosmography\" is independent of, and complementary to, other cosmological probes such as standard-candle SNIa, baryon acoustic oscillation (e.g., Eisenstein et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib46\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib46\">2005</a>; Percival et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib129\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib129\">2010</a>; Anderson et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib4\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib4\">2014</a>; Alam et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib3\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib3\">2017</a>; Wang et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib188\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib188\">2017</a>; Zhao et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib196\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib196\">2017</a>), and the fluctuation spectrum of the cosmic microwave background (e.g., Bennett et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib11\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib11\">2013</a>; Planck Collaboration et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib131\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib131\">2016</a>). Further observational development of the time-delay cosmography method is strongly motivated because the combination of different probes can mitigate the cosmological parameter degeneracies of each individual method. Furthermore, the lensed source is usually magnified by a factor of 10 or more, which makes studies of faint objects beyond the detection limit feasible (e.g., Bolton et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib19\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib19\">2006b</a>; Quider et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib135\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib135\">2009</a>; Christensen et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib31\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib31\">2012</a>; Muzzin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib120\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib120\">2012</a>; Bussmann et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib26\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib26\">2013</a>; Stark et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib165\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib165\">2015</a>; Karman et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib81\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib81\">2016</a>; Shu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib153\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib153\">2016c</a>; Spilker et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib161\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib161\">2016</a>).</p><p>The combination of these two tools in the single phenomenon of strongly lensed SNe provides a simultaneous probe of cosmology and of SN physics. All but one time-delay cosmography measurement to-date have used the relatively more common phenomenon of strongly lensed quasi-stellar objects (QSOs). Compared to lensed QSOs, lensed SNe (and especially lensed SNIa) are more powerful for cosmological measurements because (1) the optical light curves from which time delays are determined are more regular and better understood for SNe (e.g., Barbon et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib8\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib8\">1979</a>; Doggett &amp; Branch <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib42\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib42\">1985</a>; Kasen &amp; Woosley <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib82\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib82\">2009</a>; Sanders et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib146\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib146\">2015</a>; Morozova et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib115\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib115\">2017</a>) and (2) the intrinsic luminosity of some SNe can be inferred independently of lensing to constrain the absolute lensing magnifications. This extra constraint can be used to break known degeneracies in the lens modeling (e.g., Falco et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib47\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib47\">1985</a>; Gorenstein et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib62\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib62\">1988</a>; Saha <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib143\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib143\">2000</a>; Wucknitz <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib192\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib192\">2002</a>; Liesenborgs &amp; De Rijcke <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib98\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib98\">2012</a>; Schneider &amp; Sluse <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib148\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib148\">2013</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib149\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib149\">2014</a>) and lead to a more accurate measurement of the Hubble constant, provided the effects from microlensing can be corrected (e.g., Dobler &amp; Keeton <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib41\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib41\">2006</a>; Yahalomi et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib195\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib195\">2017</a>; Foxley-Marrable et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib52\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib52\">2018</a>; Goldstein et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib60\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib60\">2018</a>). Furthermore, time delays between lensed images make strong gravitational lensing a natural <em>time machine</em>. The typical time delays in galaxy-scale strong lenses are on the order of 1 day to 100 days. One can thus monitor the SN explosion at the predicted location and time after detecting the leading lensed image, and catch the trailing images early in the explosive phase. It is in fact possible to watch the same explosion multiple times if there are more than two lensed images (e.g., Kelly et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib84\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib84\">2015</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib85\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib85\">2016</a>). A significant sample of strongly lensed SNe could therefore provide significant improvement in our understanding of pre- and early explosion progenitor properties, especially in combination with the lensing magnification effect.</p><p>Despite the great power of strongly lensed SN systems, there have been only three serendipitous discoveries to date (Quimby et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib136\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib136\">2014</a>; Kelly et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib84\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib84\">2015</a>; Goobar et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib61\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib61\">2017</a>). The difficulty comes from the fact that a strongly lensed SN system is an <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/864/1/91/Full/apjaad5eaieqn1.gif\" alt=\"${ \\mathcal O }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{ \\mathcal O }</script></span></span>(rare<sup>3</sup>) event. Strong-lensing events (i.e., with multiple lensed images) are rare because they require a close alignment between the observer, the lens, and the source. Studies suggest that the strong-lens event rate on galaxy scales is on the order of 1 in 1000 (e.g., Bolton et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib17\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib17\">2006a</a>; Marshall et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib106\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib106\">2009</a>). At the same time, SN events are rare too. The SN rate in starburst galaxies is found to be a few to 10 events per century (e.g., Tammann et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib174\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib174\">1994</a>; Richmond et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib139\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib139\">1998</a>; Mannucci et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib102\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib102\">2003</a>; Diehl et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib39\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib39\">2006</a>; Adams et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib2\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib2\">2013</a>). Finally, SNe fade after explosion on rest-frame timescales of ~50 days (e.g., Richardson et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib137\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib137\">2002</a>; Li et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib97\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib97\">2011c</a>). Therefore, observations need to be made in the window before the SNe go below the detection limits.</p><p>A large sample of strongly lensed SNe is expected to be discovered by the upcoming Large Synoptic Survey Telescope (LSST) project. Oguri &amp; Marshall (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib126\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib126\">2010</a>) predict that LSST will discover 46 strongly lensed SNIa and 84 strongly lensed core-collapse SN (CCSN, including Type Ib/c and Type II) events with image separations larger than 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />5 in 10 years. Kostrzewa-Rutkowska et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib91\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib91\">2013</a>) and Goldstein &amp; Nugent (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib59\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib59\">2017</a>) predict furthermore that LSST will detect 220\u20131400 strongly lensed SNIa and ~3800 strongly lensed CCSN events with image separations as small as 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />1 in 10 years. The numbers of strongly lensed SNe in these latter predictions become similar to the prediction of Oguri &amp; Marshall (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib126\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib126\">2010</a>) if limited to events with image separations larger than 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />5 and magnifications solely due to brightest images. Further limiting to median image separations larger than 2'', Goldstein &amp; Nugent (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib59\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib59\">2017</a>) predict that LSST will detect an average of five (this number is estimated from their Figure 5 as ~20%\u201325% of the total predictions) strongly lensed SNIa events per year.</p><p>In this paper, we propose a new strategy of finding strongly lensed SNe through monitoring of a sample of known galaxy-scale strong-lens systems. The advantages of this strategy are three-fold. First, any SN occurring at the location of a known strongly lensed star-forming galaxy has a significantly higher probability of being strongly lensed and multiply imaged, as compared to an SN detected in the field. Second, the multiple SN images detected in this sample will have the same relatively wide image separations as their lensed host galaxies (median of 2''), facilitating intensive early time observation of trailing images and precise measurements of time delays. Lastly, compared to galaxy clusters behind which previous searches for lensed SNe were carried out (e.g. Goobar et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib62a\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib62a\">2009</a>; Postman et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib132a\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib132a\">2012</a>; Pan &amp; Lobe <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib128a\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib128a\">2013</a>; Rodney et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib141a\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib141a\">2015</a>; Petrushevska et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib131a\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib131a\">2016</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib131b\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib131b\">2018</a>), the foreground lens objects of our work as primarily isolated early-type galaxies, which have relatively smooth and simple mass profiles that can be more robustly constrained from lensing data when compared to galaxy groups or clusters. This advantage is significant for the application of detected strongly lensed SNe to time-delay cosmography.</p><p>This paper is organized as follows. Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaad5eas2\">2</a> introduces the compilation of strong-lens systems used. Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaad5eas3\">3</a> describes our procedure for estimating the star formation rates and SN rates in the lensed sources. Predictions for detectable SN rates given particular survey depths are presented in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaad5eas4\">4</a>. Discussions and conclusions are given in Sections <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaad5eas5\">5</a> and <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaad5eas6\">6</a>. Throughout the paper, we adopt a fiducial cosmological model with \u03a9<sub>m</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.308, \u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.692, and <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>\u00a0=\u00a067.8 km s<sup>\u22121</sup> Mpc<sup>\u22121</sup> (Planck Collaboration et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib131\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib131\">2016</a>).</p></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjaad5eas2\" name=\"apjaad5eas2\">2.\u00a0Strong-lens Sample Compilation</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>To date, almost 300 galaxy-scale strong-lens systems have been discovered (e.g., Walsh et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib186\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib186\">1979</a>; Mu\u00f1oz et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib119\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib119\">1998</a>; Browne et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib24\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib24\">2003</a>; Bolton et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib16\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib16\">2008</a>; Faure et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib48\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib48\">2008</a>; Treu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib180\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib180\">2011</a>; Brownstein et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib25\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib25\">2012</a>; Inada et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib76\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib76\">2012</a>; More et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib111\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib111\">2012</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib113\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib113\">2016</a>; Sonnenfeld et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib159\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib159\">2013</a>; Stark et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib164\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib164\">2013</a>; Vieira et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib185\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib185\">2013</a>; Pawase et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib128\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib128\">2014</a>; Shu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib152\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib152\">2016b</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib154\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib154\">2017</a>; Negrello et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib121\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib121\">2017</a>; Sonnenfeld et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib158\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib158\">2018</a>). In this work, we build a compilation of 128 strong-lens systems from the Sloan Lens ACS Survey (SLACS; Bolton et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib16\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib16\">2008</a>, 63 systems), the SLACS for the Masses Survey (S4TM; Shu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib154\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib154\">2017</a>, 40 systems), and the Baryon Oscillation Spectroscopy Survey (BOSS) Emission-Line Lens Survey (BELLS; Brownstein et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib25\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib25\">2012</a>, 25 systems). The strong-lens systems in these three surveys are selected by the technique introduced in Bolton et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib18\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib18\">2004</a>), which ensures that the lensing object is a massive early-type galaxy while the lensed object is a galaxy with significant star formation as indicated by the securely detected [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]<em>\u03bb \u03bb</em>3727 emission along with (in many cases) H<em>\u03b2</em>, [O <span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>]4959, [O <span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>]5007, and H<em>\u03b1</em> emission. Accurate lens models have been derived from <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>) imaging data for all the systems. The lens and source redshifts are spectroscopically determined. The median lens and source redshifts for the SLACS, S4TM, and BELLS lens samples are (<em>z</em><sub><em>L</em></sub> = 0.20, <em>z</em><sub><em>S</em></sub> = 0.60), (<em>z</em><sub><em>L</em></sub> = 0.16, <em>z</em><sub><em>S</em></sub> = 0.59), and (<em>z</em><sub><em>L</em></sub> = 0.52, <em>z</em><sub><em>S</em></sub> = 1.18), respectively. The median image separation in this compilation is 2''.</p></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjaad5eas3\" name=\"apjaad5eas3\">3.\u00a0Star Formation Rate and Supernova Rates</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>The rate of core-collapse SN (CCSN, including Type Ib/c and Type II) in a galaxy, associated with the final collapse of short-lived massive stars, is significantly correlated with the star formation rate (SFR; e.g., Madau et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib100\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib100\">1998</a>; Dahl\u00e9n &amp; Fransson <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib34\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib34\">1999</a>; Hopkins &amp; Beacom <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib72\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib72\">2006</a>; Dahlen et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib36\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib36\">2012</a>; Melinder et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib110\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib110\">2012</a>). The rate of SNIa depends on other host-galaxy properties in addition to SFR (e.g., Sullivan et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib168\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib168\">2006</a>; Li et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib96\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib96\">2011b</a>; Smith et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib155\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib155\">2012</a>; Graur et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib64\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib64\">2015</a>). Following previous work (e.g., Greggio et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib65\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib65\">2008</a>; Maoz et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib104\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib104\">2011</a>), we determine the SNIa rate in our sample by convolving the star formation history (SFH) with the SNIa delay-time distribution, which has been calibrated against observations to account for some of the most important host-galaxy property dependences (for instance, on host-galaxy mass and age.)</p><h3 id=\"apjaad5eas3-1\" name=\"apjaad5eas3-1\">3.1.\u00a0Intrinsic [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] Flux Determination</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>To enable SFR estimation, we first determine the intrinsic integrated [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] flux of each lensed source, which has been shown to be an empirical SFR indicator (e.g., Gallagher et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib53\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib53\">1989</a>; Kennicutt <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib87\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib87\">1992</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib88\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib88\">1998</a>; Hogg et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib71\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib71\">1998</a>; Jansen et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib78\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib78\">2001</a>; Cardiel et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib30\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib30\">2003</a>; Hopkins et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib73\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib73\">2003</a>; Kewley et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib89\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib89\">2004</a>; Moustakas et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib118\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib118\">2006</a>; Gilbank et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib57\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib57\">2010</a>; Hayashi et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib67\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib67\">2013</a>). We note that a small fraction (~10%) of our lensed sources also shows H<em>\u03b1</em> emission in the optical spectroscopic data, which is, in principle, a better SFR indicator than [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] (e.g., Kennicutt <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib86\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib86\">1983</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib88\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib88\">1998</a>; Moustakas et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib118\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib118\">2006</a>). Nevertheless, for uniformity, we only use [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] flux for the SFR estimation for the entire sample.</p><p>The observed integrated [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] flux, <em>F</em><sub>[O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]</sub>, is measured from the SDSS or BOSS spectrum, collected by a fiber centered on the lens galaxy. The lens-galaxy spectrum is first subtracted following procedures in Bolton et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib17\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib17\">2006a</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib20\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib20\">2012b</a>), Brownstein et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib25\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib25\">2012</a>), and Shu et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib151\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib151\">2016a</a>). The [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emission profile is then fitted by a double Gaussian plus a first-order polynomial (i.e., a line). The ratio of the central wavelengths of the two Gaussians is fixed to 3727.09/3729.88. The parameter optimization is done using the Levenberg\u2013Marquardt algorithm implemented in the <tt>MPFIT</tt> package (Markwardt <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib105\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib105\">2009</a>). The best-fit integrated [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] fluxes of the lensed sources are provided in Column (7) of Tabel <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjaad5eat1\">1</a>. Note that we choose not to report results for 18 systems for which the inferred [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] flux error is larger than the best-fit [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] flux. Calculations of the SFR and SN rates in the rest of the paper are based on the remaining 110 strong-lens systems after excluding these 18.</p><p>To obtain the intrinsic [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] integrated flux, we correct for the lensing magnification and fiber loss, as inferred from the strong-lens models. For the S4TM lensed sources, we use the lens models from Shu et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib154\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib154\">2017</a>). We remodel the SLACS strong-lens systems following the same methodology as Shu et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib154\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib154\">2017</a>) because their lensing magnifications are not publicly available. For consistency, we also remodel the BELLS strong-lens systems in the same way. We calculate the total magnification, <em>\u03bc</em>, for each lens system. To quantify the uncertainty in <em>\u03bc</em> due to different lens-modeling tools, we compare our values to the published values in Brownstein et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib25\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib25\">2012</a>) for the 25 BELLS strong-lens systems. The average <em>\u03bc</em> ratio, defined as <em>\u03bc</em><sub>this work</sub>/<em>\u03bc</em><sub>Brownstein2012</sub>, is 0.94, indicating relatively little bias in the <em>\u03bc</em> determination. The standard deviation of the <em>\u03bc</em>-ratio distribution is 0.16, which we adopt as the fractional uncertainty in <em>\u03bc</em>. The fraction of the lensed source flux captured by either the 3''-diameter fiber (for SLACS and S4TM lenses) or the 2''-diameter fiber (for BELLS lenses), denoted as <em>f</em><sub>fiber</sub>, is determined by convolving the best-fit model of the lensed images obtained from the <em>HST</em> imaging data with the ground-based point-spread function of the spectroscopic observation. A top-hat kernel matched with the specific fiber size is then applied to the convolved image to determine <em>f</em><sub>fiber</sub>. Columns (5) and (6) of Tabel <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjaad5eat1\">1</a> list <em>\u03bc</em> and <em>f</em><sub>fiber</sub> values. The intrinsic source [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] integrated flux is then computed as</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjaad5eaeqn1\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/864/1/91/Full/apjaad5eaeqn1.gif\" alt=\"Equation (1)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{F}_{[{\\rm{O}}\\,{\\rm{II}}]}^{\\mathrm{intrinsic}}={F}_{[{\\rm{O}}{\\rm{II}}]}/{f}_{\\mathrm{fiber}}/\\mu .\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t1\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>\n</p><p>Note that all the strong-lens models, and hence the derived <em>\u03bc</em> and <em>f</em><sub>fiber</sub> quantities, are based on <em>HST</em> F814W wide-band imaging data, which covers roughly 7500 \u00c5\u20139500 \u00c5 in the observed frame. In the source rest frame, these <em>HST</em> observations probe continuum emission at 4500 \u00c5\u20136000 \u00c5 (for the SLACS and S4TM lensed sources with an average redshift of 0.6) and 3400 \u00c5\u20134300 \u00c5 (for the BELLS lensed sources with an average redshift of 1.2). Strictly speaking, the derived <em>\u03bc</em> and <em>f</em><sub>fiber</sub> apply to the source continuum-emitting regions. We nevertheless adopt these as the values for the source [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emitting regions simply because no other data are available for better determinations of <em>\u03bc</em> and <em>f</em><sub>fiber</sub> of [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emission. At least for BELLS lensed sources, this approximation should be reasonably accurate because the [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emission is driven by the ultraviolet (UV) radiation from massive young stars, which are also primarily responsible for the UV continuum emission around 3400 \u00c5\u20134300 \u00c5.</p><p>The distributions of <em>\u03bc</em> and <em>f</em><sub>fiber</sub> for the full sample, as well as for each individual lens sample, are shown in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaad5eaf1\">1</a>. The <em>\u03bc</em>-histogram of the full sample suggests that the probability density function (PDF) of log<sub>10</sub><em>\u03bc</em> can be well characterized by a skew-normal function as</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjaad5eaeqn2\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/864/1/91/Full/apjaad5eaeqn2.gif\" alt=\"Equation (2)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&p({\\mathrm{log}}_{10}\\mu )=\\displaystyle \\frac{2}{{\\sigma }_{{\\mathrm{log}}_{10}\\mu }}\\phi \\left(\\displaystyle \\frac{{\\mathrm{log}}_{10}(\\mu /{\\mu }_{0})}{{\\sigma }_{{\\mathrm{log}}_{10}\\mu }}\\right){\\rm{\\Phi }}\\left(\\alpha \\left(\\displaystyle \\frac{{\\mathrm{log}}_{10}(\\mu /{\\mu }_{0})}{{\\sigma }_{{\\mathrm{log}}_{10}\\mu }}\\right)\\right),\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t2\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>in which <em><img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/phgr.gif\" alt=\"phgr\" align=\"absmiddle\" /></em>(<em>x</em>) and \u03a6(<em>x</em>) are the PDF and cumulative density function of a Gaussian distribution, respectively. The three parameters <em>\u03bc</em><sub>0</sub>, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/864/1/91/Full/apjaad5eaieqn2.gif\" alt=\"${\\sigma }_{{\\mathrm{log}}_{10}\\mu }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\sigma }_{{\\mathrm{log}}_{10}\\mu }</script></span></span>, and <em>\u03b1</em> describe the location, scale, and degree of skewness of the log<sub>10</sub><em>\u03bc</em> PDF (respectively). The gray curve in the left panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaad5eaf1\">1</a> shows the best skew-normal fit to the histogram of the full sample (in black) with</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjaad5eaeqn3\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/864/1/91/Full/apjaad5eaeqn3.gif\" alt=\"Equation (3)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{\\mu }_{0}=5.0\\pm 1.9,\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t3\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjaad5eaeqn4\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/864/1/91/Full/apjaad5eaeqn4.gif\" alt=\"Equation (4)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{\\sigma }_{{\\mathrm{log}}_{10}\\mu }=0.91\\pm 0.09,\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t4\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjaad5eaeqn5\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/864/1/91/Full/apjaad5eaeqn5.gif\" alt=\"Equation (5)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&\\alpha =2.5\\pm 1.0.\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t5\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>We find that the <em>\u03bc</em>-distributions of the three individual lens samples (as shown by the dashed histograms in color) show no significant deviation from that of the full sample.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjaad5eaf1\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjaad5eaf1\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/864/1/91/Full/apjaad5eaf1_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 1.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 1.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/864/1/91/Full/apjaad5eaf1_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 1.</strong>\u00a0Histograms of the total magnification, <em>\u03bc</em>, and the fraction of flux captured by the fiber, <em>f</em><sub>fiber</sub>, derived from the best-fit lens models for the full lens compilation (solid black) as well as the three individual lens samples (dashed colors). The gray lines represent the best analytical fits to the full-sample histograms.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjaad5eaf1\" href=\"/0004-637X/864/1/91/downloadFigure/figure/apjaad5eaf1\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjaad5eaf1\" href=\"/0004-637X/864/1/91/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjaad5eaf1\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>The <em>f</em><sub>fiber</sub> PDF of the full sample can be approximated as a Gaussian function with best-fit mean <em>f</em><sub>fiber,0</sub> and standard deviation <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/864/1/91/Full/apjaad5eaieqn3.gif\" alt=\"${\\sigma }_{{f}_{\\mathrm{fiber}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\sigma }_{{f}_{\\mathrm{fiber}}}</script></span></span> parameters given by</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjaad5eaeqn6\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/864/1/91/Full/apjaad5eaeqn6.gif\" alt=\"Equation (6)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{f}_{\\mathrm{fiber},0}=0.44\\pm 0.02,\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t6\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjaad5eaeqn7\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/864/1/91/Full/apjaad5eaeqn7.gif\" alt=\"Equation (7)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{\\sigma }_{{f}_{\\mathrm{fiber}}}=0.16\\pm 0.02.\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t7\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>The distributions of the individual lens samples are similar at small <em>f</em><sub>fiber</sub> values, but become significantly different at large <em>f</em><sub>fiber</sub>. The BELLS lens sample does not have any system with <em>f</em><sub>fiber</sub>\u00a0&gt;\u00a060%. This is primarily related to the fact that the fiber size for BELLS lens systems is more than 30% smaller than that of SLACS and S4TM lens systems. On the other hand, over 40% of the S4TM lens systems have <em>f</em><sub>fiber</sub>\u00a0&gt;\u00a060%, which is much larger than the fraction for the SLACS lens systems (&lt;5%) with the same fiber size. We attribute this difference to the fact that the S4TM lens galaxies are, on average, a factor of two less massive than the SLACS lens galaxies as found in Shu et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib154\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib154\">2017</a>). With similar lens and source redshifts, the less massive S4TM lens galaxies form lensed images with smaller angular separations, which are more likely to be covered by the fiber.</p></div><h3 id=\"apjaad5eas3-2\" name=\"apjaad5eas3-2\">3.2.\u00a0Star Formation Rate from [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] Luminosity</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>Additional calibration is generally needed for an [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]-derived SFR because [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emission is not directly coupled to the ionizing flux alone, but rather is also sensitive to the oxygen abundance. In addition, the intrinsic [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] luminosity cannot be accurately inferred without correction for dust extinction. Various studies have attempted to calibrate the [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]-derived SFR against other observables such as oxygen abundance, [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]/H<em>\u03b1</em> line ratio, broadband luminosity, stellar mass, and [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] equivalent width (e.g., Hicks et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib69\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib69\">2002</a>; Kewley et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib89\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib89\">2004</a>; Moustakas et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib118\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib118\">2006</a>; Argence &amp; Lamareille <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib5\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib5\">2009</a>; Gilbank et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib57\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib57\">2010</a>; Mostek et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib117\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib117\">2012</a>; Hayashi et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib67\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib67\">2013</a>; Talia et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib173\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib173\">2015</a>). However, due to the limited data available for the lensed sources, we cannot perform a full calibration on a system-by-system basis. Instead, we analyze the subsample of our lens compilation with detected H<em>\u03b1</em> emission, and apply the resulting calibration to the full sample.</p><p>H<em>\u03b1</em> luminosity is one of the most reliable SFR indicators, since it scales directly with ionizing flux. A commonly used conversion due to Kennicutt (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib88\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib88\">1998</a>) is</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjaad5eaeqn8\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/864/1/91/Full/apjaad5eaeqn8.gif\" alt=\"Equation (8)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&\\displaystyle \\frac{\\mathrm{SFR}}{{M}_{\\odot }\\,{\\mathrm{yr}}^{-1}}=7.9\\times {10}^{-42}\\displaystyle \\frac{{L}_{{\\rm{H}}\\alpha }}{\\mathrm{erg}\\ {{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}},\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t8\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>which assumes no dust and a Salpeter initial mass function (IMF, Salpeter <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib145\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib145\">1955</a>). Here, <em>L</em><sub>H<em>\u03b1</em></sub> is the intrinsic H<em>\u03b1</em> luminosity. In the presence of dust, we can rewrite this relation as</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjaad5eaueqn1\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/864/1/91/Full/apjaad5eaueqn1.gif\" alt=\"\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray*}&&\\displaystyle \\frac{\\mathrm{SFR}}{{M}_{\\odot }\\,{\\mathrm{yr}}^{-1}}=7.9\\times {10}^{-42}\\displaystyle \\frac{{10}^{0.4{A}_{{\\rm{H}}\\alpha }}{L}_{{\\rm{H}}\\alpha }^{\\mathrm{obs}}}{\\mathrm{erg}\\ {{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}},\\end{eqnarray*}</script></span></div><p>in which <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/864/1/91/Full/apjaad5eaieqn4.gif\" alt=\"${L}_{{\\rm{H}}\\alpha }^{\\mathrm{obs}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{L}_{{\\rm{H}}\\alpha }^{\\mathrm{obs}}</script></span></span> is the observed H<em>\u03b1</em> luminosity and <em>A</em><sub>H<em>\u03b1</em></sub> is the dust extinction at the wavelength of H<em>\u03b1</em>. We can further transform the conversion as</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjaad5eaueqn2\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/864/1/91/Full/apjaad5eaueqn2.gif\" alt=\"\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray*}&&\\displaystyle \\frac{\\mathrm{SFR}}{{M}_{\\odot }\\,{\\mathrm{yr}}^{-1}}=\\displaystyle \\frac{{10}^{0.4{A}_{{\\rm{H}}\\alpha }}}{{F}_{[{\\rm{O}}{\\rm{II}}]}/{F}_{{\\rm{H}}\\alpha }}\\displaystyle \\frac{{L}_{[{\\rm{O}}\\,{\\rm{II}}]}^{\\mathrm{obs}}}{1.27\\,\\times \\,{10}^{41}\\,\\mathrm{erg}\\ {{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}},\\end{eqnarray*}</script></span></div><p>in which <em>F</em><sub>[O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]</sub>, <em>F</em><sub>H<em>\u03b1</em></sub>, and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/864/1/91/Full/apjaad5eaieqn5.gif\" alt=\"${L}_{[{\\rm{O}}\\,{\\rm{II}}]}^{\\mathrm{obs}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{L}_{[{\\rm{O}}\\,{\\rm{II}}]}^{\\mathrm{obs}}</script></span></span> are the observed, dust-extinction uncorrected [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] flux, H<em>\u03b1</em> flux, and [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] luminosity, respectively. The [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] luminosity is simply computed from the [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] flux <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/864/1/91/Full/apjaad5eaieqn6.gif\" alt=\"${F}_{[{\\rm{O}}\\,{\\rm{II}}]}^{\\mathrm{intrinsic}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{F}_{[{\\rm{O}}\\,{\\rm{II}}]}^{\\mathrm{intrinsic}}</script></span></span> as</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjaad5eaeqn9\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/864/1/91/Full/apjaad5eaeqn9.gif\" alt=\"Equation (9)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{L}_{[{\\rm{O}}{\\rm{II}}]}=4\\pi {D}_{L}^{2}({z}_{S}){F}_{[{\\rm{O}}\\,{\\rm{II}}]}^{\\mathrm{intrinsic}},\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t9\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where <em>D</em><sub><em>L</em></sub> (<em>z</em><sub><em>S</em></sub>) is the luminosity distance at the source redshift <em>z</em><sub><em>S</em></sub>.</p><p>We use the 12 strong-lens systems with simultaneously detected H<em>\u03b1</em> emissions to establish a fiducial [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]/H<em>\u03b1</em> ratio for the full lens compilation. We fit a single Gaussian plus a first-order polynomial to the observed H<em>\u03b1</em> emission in the residual spectrum to obtain the observed H<em>\u03b1</em> flux for these 12 lensed sources. We find that the H<em>\u03b1</em>/[O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] flux ratio is centered at 1.2 with a scatter of 0.5, consistent with the results in Hayashi et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib67\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib67\">2013</a>), who studied a sample of <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.47 [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emitters. Furthermore, the typical [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] luminosity level of the full lensed source sample is about (4\u201360)\u00a0<b>&#x00d7;</b>\u00a010<sup>41</sup> erg s<sup>\u22121</sup>, which is also similar to that of the [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emitter sample in Hayashi et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib67\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib67\">2013</a>). Based on the H<em>\u03b1</em>/[O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] flux ratio, Hayashi et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib67\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib67\">2013</a>) estimated the dust extinction at H<em>\u03b1</em> to be 0.35 mag using the empirical relation from Sobral et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib156\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib156\">2012</a>). We thus assume that the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/864/1/91/Full/apjaad5eaieqn7.gif\" alt=\"${F}_{[{\\rm{O}}{\\rm{II}}]}/{F}_{{\\rm{H}}\\alpha }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{F}_{[{\\rm{O}}{\\rm{II}}]}/{F}_{{\\rm{H}}\\alpha }</script></span></span> ratio for the full lens compilation is 0.83\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.35, and <em>A</em><sub>H<em>\u03b1</em></sub> is 0.35 mag. The conversion from <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/864/1/91/Full/apjaad5eaieqn8.gif\" alt=\"${L}_{[{\\rm{O}}{\\rm{II}}]}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{L}_{[{\\rm{O}}{\\rm{II}}]}</script></span></span> to SFR now becomes</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjaad5eaeqn10\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/864/1/91/Full/apjaad5eaeqn10.gif\" alt=\"Equation (10)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&\\displaystyle \\frac{\\mathrm{SFR}}{{M}_{\\odot }\\,{\\mathrm{yr}}^{-1}}=(1.31\\pm 0.55)\\times {10}^{-41}{L}_{[{\\rm{O}}{\\rm{II}}]}.\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t10\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>Note that this conversion is obtained assuming a Salpeter IMF, while recent studies have suggested that the stellar IMF may vary with galaxy properties (e.g., Auger et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib6\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib6\">2010</a>; Treu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib179\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib179\">2010</a>; van Dokkum &amp; Conroy <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib183\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib183\">2010</a>; Strader et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib166\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib166\">2011</a>; Cappellari et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib29\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib29\">2012</a>; Sonnenfeld et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib160\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib160\">2012</a>; Spiniello et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib163\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib163\">2012</a>; Conroy et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib33\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib33\">2013</a>; Ferreras et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib49\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib49\">2013</a>; la Barbera et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib93\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib93\">2013</a>; Tortora et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib178\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib178\">2013</a>; Brewer et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib22\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib22\">2014</a>; Spiniello et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib162\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib162\">2014</a>; Shu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib150\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib150\">2015</a>; Li et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib94\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib94\">2017</a>). An extra factor of 0.67 would need to be included to convert the reported SFRs to values under the assumption of a Kroupa IMF (Kroupa <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib92\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib92\">2001</a>), to account for the mass ratio between the two IMFs for the same amount of ionizing radiation (e.g., Brinchmann et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib23\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib23\">2004</a>; Gilbank et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib57\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib57\">2010</a>).</p><p>The estimated intrinsic SFRs for the lensed sources from the above analysis are provided in Column (8) of Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjaad5eat1\">1</a>. The uncertainty in the SFR takes into account uncertainties in the apparent [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] flux, total magnification, and conversion factor from [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] luminosity to SFR. Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaad5eaf2\">2</a> shows the estimated SFR against redshift of each individual lensed sources from the three lens samples in different colors. We find that the SFRs for the lensed sources range from 0.3 <em>M</em><sub>\u2299</sub> yr<sup>\u22121</sup> to 267 <em>M</em><sub>\u2299</sub> yr<sup>\u22121</sup>. The median SFRs for the SLACS, S4TM, and BELLS lensed sources are 6 <em>M</em><sub>\u2299</sub> yr<sup>\u22121</sup>, 5 <em>M</em><sub>\u2299</sub> yr<sup>\u22121</sup>, and 68 <em>M</em><sub>\u2299</sub> yr<sup>\u22121</sup>, respectively. Furthermore, there is a strong correlation between SFR and source redshift, which is primarily a selection bias, since all the lens systems are selected to have their apparent [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] fluxes above a certain signal-to-noise ratio (S/N) threshold. One can see from Column (7) in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjaad5eat1\">1</a> that the apparent [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] flux level is indeed similar across the three lens samples. As a result, the intrinsic [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] luminosities, and hence the derived SFRs, are higher at progressively higher redshifts. To further contextualize this, we overplot the cosmic star formation history trend given by Madau &amp; Dickinson (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib101\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib101\">2014</a>, i.e., Equation (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apjaad5eaeqn16\">16</a>) in this work) in black in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaad5eaf2\">2</a>. This trend is normalized such that the SFR at <em>z</em><sub><em>S</em></sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.9, where the three lens samples overlap, is equal to the median SFR of the lensed sources within 0.85\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>z</em><sub><em>S</em></sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a00.95. It can be seen that the lensed galaxies in our combined sample are more intensely star-forming at higher redshifts, even after taking into account the cosmic evolution of the SFR.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjaad5eaf2\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjaad5eaf2\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/864/1/91/Full/apjaad5eaf2_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 2.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 2.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/864/1/91/Full/apjaad5eaf2_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 2.</strong>\u00a0SFR-redshift relation for the SLACS (in green), S4TM (in blue), and BELLS (in red) lensed sources. The black line represents the SFR-redshift relation defined in Equation (<a class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apjaad5eaeqn16\">16</a>) normalized at <em>z</em><sub><em>S</em></sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.9 where the three lens samples have a substantial overlap.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjaad5eaf2\" href=\"/0004-637X/864/1/91/downloadFigure/figure/apjaad5eaf2\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjaad5eaf2\" href=\"/0004-637X/864/1/91/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjaad5eaf2\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apjaad5eat1\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 1.</b>\u00a0\nUseful Properties of the Compilation of Strong Lenses\n</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjaad5eat1\" data-toolbar-img=\"/0004-637X/864/1/91/suppdata/apjaad5eat1_lr.gif\" data-toolbar-type=\"table\" data-toolbar-title=\"Table 1\"><colgroup><col align=\"left\" char=\"\"></col><col align=\"left\" char=\"\"></col><col align=\"left\" char=\"\"></col><col align=\"left\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">SFR</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\"><em>N</em><sub>cc</sub></th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">(4)</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">(5)</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">(6)</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">(7)</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">(8)</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" align=\"center\">43%</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">\u22ef</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">\u22ef</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">00:29:07.77\u221200:55:50.50</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.23</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.93</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">23</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">61%</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">SLACSJ 0037\u22120942</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">00:37:53.22\u221209:42:20.14</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.20</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.63</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">6</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">34%</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\"\u00b1\">2.2\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.5</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\"
