char=\"\u00b1\">0.0040\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0020</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table><p><small>\n<p><strong>Note.</strong> Column 1 is the system name with leading letters indicating the specific survey program. Column 2 is the system position in right ascension and declination. Columns 3 and 4 are the lens and source redshifts inferred from the SDSS/BOSS spectrum. Column 5 provides the inferred total magnification from the best-fit lens model. Columns 6 and 7 are the fraction of source flux and apparent [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] flux (in units of 10<sup>\u221216</sup> erg s<sup>\u22121</sup> cm<sup>2</sup>) collected by the SDSS/BOSS fiber. Columns 8 is the intrinsic SFR estimated from [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] flux. Columns 9 and 10 are the core-collapse SN rate, and Type-Ia SN rate inferred from the SFR. Asterisked are systems with simultaneous H<em>\u03b1</em> detections.</p>\n</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/864/1/91/suppdata/apjaad5eat1_ascii.txt?doi=10.3847/1538-4357/aad5ea\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a>Typeset images: <a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset-multiple typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/864/1/91/suppdata/apjaad5eat1_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">1</a> <a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset-multiple typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/864/1/91/suppdata/apjaad5eat1a_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">2</a> <a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset-multiple typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/864/1/91/suppdata/apjaad5eat1b_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">3</a> </span></p></div></div><h3 id=\"apjaad5eas3-3\" name=\"apjaad5eas3-3\">3.3.\u00a0Supernova Rates from Star Formation Rate</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><h4 id=\"apjaad5eas3-3-1\" name=\"apjaad5eas3-3-1\">3.3.1.\u00a0Core-collapse Supernova Rate</h4><div class=\"article-text\"><p>The rate of CCSNe is proportional to recent SFRs (e.g., Dahl\u00e9n &amp; Fransson <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib34\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib34\">1999</a>; Oguri &amp; Marshall <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib126\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib126\">2010</a>) according to the relation</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjaad5eaeqn11\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/864/1/91/Full/apjaad5eaeqn11.gif\" alt=\"Equation (11)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{N}_{\\mathrm{cc}}=\\displaystyle \\frac{1}{1+{z}_{S}}{k}_{\\mathrm{cc}}\\times \\mathrm{SFR},\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t11\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>in which <em>k</em><sub>cc</sub> is the number of CCSNe per unit mass, and <em>N</em><sub>cc</sub> is the occurrence rate of CCSNe per year. An extra factor of (1 + <em>z</em><sub><em>S</em></sub>)<sup>\u22121</sup> is applied to account for the time dilation because the derived SFRs are values in the lensed source rest frame while we are interested in the SN rates in the observed frame (the same factor is applied to the SNIa rate calculation below as well). Effectively, <em>k</em><sub>cc</sub> is the number of CCSN progenitors per unit mass, averaged across all recently formed stars. Assuming a particular IMF, <em><img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/phgr.gif\" alt=\"phgr\" align=\"absmiddle\" /></em>(<em>m</em>), <em>k</em><sub>cc</sub> can be computed as</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjaad5eaeqn12\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/864/1/91/Full/apjaad5eaeqn12.gif\" alt=\"Equation (12)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{k}_{\\mathrm{cc}}=\\displaystyle \\frac{{\\int }_{{M}_{1}}^{{M}_{2}}\\phi (M){dM}}{{\\int }_{{M}_{\\min }}^{{M}_{\\max }}M\\,\\phi (M){dM}},\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t12\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>in which <em>M</em><sub>min</sub> and <em>M</em><sub>max</sub> are the lower and upper cutoff masses for the considered IMF, and <em>M</em><sub>1</sub>\u2013<em>M</em><sub>2</sub> represents the mass range of CCSN progenitors. To be consistent with the IMF choice for the SFR estimation, we choose a Salpeter IMF with <em>M</em><sub>min</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.1<em>M</em><sub>\u2299</sub> and <em>M</em><sub>max</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0125<em>M</em><sub>\u2299</sub>. The mass range of CCSN progenitors is assumed to be 8\u201350 <em>M</em><sub>\u2299</sub>, since more massive stars likely form black holes instead of SNe (e.g., Tsujimoto et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib182\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib182\">1997</a>; Hopkins &amp; Beacom <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib72\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib72\">2006</a>; Oguri &amp; Marshall <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib126\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib126\">2010</a>; Dahlen et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib36\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib36\">2012</a>; Melinder et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib110\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib110\">2012</a>). Under these assumptions, <em>k</em><sub>cc</sub> is computed to be 0.0070 <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/864/1/91/Full/apjaad5eaieqn9.gif\" alt=\"${M}_{\\odot }^{-1}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{M}_{\\odot }^{-1}</script></span></span>. Note that Strolger et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib167\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib167\">2015</a>) empirically found <em>k</em><sub>cc</sub> to be 0.0091\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0017 <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/864/1/91/Full/apjaad5eaieqn10.gif\" alt=\"${M}_{\\odot }^{-1}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{M}_{\\odot }^{-1}</script></span></span>, broadly consistent with the value we adopt here.</p></div><h4 id=\"apjaad5eas3-3-2\" name=\"apjaad5eas3-3-2\">3.3.2.\u00a0Type Ia Supernova Rate</h4><div class=\"article-text\"><p>In principle, the occurrence rate of SNIa can be similarly estimated (e.g., Dahl\u00e9n &amp; Fransson <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib34\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib34\">1999</a>; Oguri &amp; Marshall <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib126\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib126\">2010</a>) according to</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjaad5eaeqn13\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/864/1/91/Full/apjaad5eaeqn13.gif\" alt=\"Equation (13)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{N}_{\\mathrm{Ia}}=\\eta \\,{C}_{\\mathrm{Ia}}\\displaystyle \\frac{{\\int }_{{t}_{\\min }}^{t({z}_{S})}\\mathrm{SFR}(t({z}_{S})-{t}_{{\\rm{D}}}){f}_{{\\rm{D}}}({t}_{{\\rm{D}}};\\tau ){{dt}}_{{\\rm{D}}}}{(1+{z}_{S}){\\int }_{{t}_{\\min }}^{t(0)}{f}_{{\\rm{D}}}({t}_{{\\rm{D}}};\\tau ){{dt}}_{{\\rm{D}}}}\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t13\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjaad5eaeqn14\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/864/1/91/Full/apjaad5eaeqn14.gif\" alt=\"Equation (14)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{C}_{\\mathrm{Ia}}=\\displaystyle \\frac{{\\int }_{{M}_{1}^{{\\prime} }}^{{M}_{2}^{{\\prime} }}\\phi (M){dM}}{{\\int }_{{M}_{\\min }}^{{M}_{\\max }}m\\,\\phi (M){dM}},\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t14\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>in which <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/864/1/91/Full/apjaad5eaieqn11.gif\" alt=\"${M}_{1}^{{\\prime} }=3\\,{M}_{\\odot }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{M}_{1}^{{\\prime} }=3\\,{M}_{\\odot }</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/864/1/91/Full/apjaad5eaieqn12.gif\" alt=\"${M}_{2}^{{\\prime} }=8\\,{M}_{\\odot }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{M}_{2}^{{\\prime} }=8\\,{M}_{\\odot }</script></span></span> are the mass limits of SNIa progenitors, <em>\u03b7</em> is the fraction of progenitors that successfully explode as an SNIa, and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/864/1/91/Full/apjaad5eaieqn13.gif\" alt=\"${f}_{{\\rm{D}}}({t}_{{\\rm{D}}};\\tau )$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{f}_{{\\rm{D}}}({t}_{{\\rm{D}}};\\tau )</script></span></span> is the delay-time (<em>t</em><sub>D</sub>) distribution with a characteristic timescale <em>\u03c4</em> and a minimum delay time <em>t</em><sub>min</sub>. However, this conversion is subject to significant systematics. In particular, <em>\u03b7</em>, <em>\u03c4</em>, and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/864/1/91/Full/apjaad5eaieqn14.gif\" alt=\"${f}_{{\\rm{D}}}({t}_{{\\rm{D}}};\\tau )$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{f}_{{\\rm{D}}}({t}_{{\\rm{D}}};\\tau )</script></span></span> are not well constrained. Usually, <em>\u03b7</em> is calibrated by matching the predicted rate at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00 to the observed SNIa rate in the local universe. The typical value for <em>\u03b7</em> is 4%\u201310% (e.g., Madau et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib100\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib100\">1998</a>; Dahlen et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib35\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib35\">2004</a>; Hopkins &amp; Beacom <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib72\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib72\">2006</a>; Maoz et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib103\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib103\">2012</a>), which depends on the assumed delay-time distribution and <em>\u03c4</em> value. To be conservative, we choose <em>\u03b7</em>\u00a0=\u00a04%. Again choosing a Salpeter IMF, we have</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjaad5eaeqn15\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/864/1/91/Full/apjaad5eaeqn15.gif\" alt=\"Equation (15)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{N}_{\\mathrm{Ia}}=0.00084{M}_{\\odot }^{-1}\\displaystyle \\frac{{\\int }_{{t}_{\\min }}^{t({z}_{S})}\\mathrm{SFR}(t({z}_{S})-{t}_{{\\rm{D}}}){f}_{{\\rm{D}}}({t}_{{\\rm{D}}};\\tau ){{dt}}_{{\\rm{D}}}}{(1+{z}_{S}){\\int }_{{t}_{\\min }}^{t(0)}{f}_{{\\rm{D}}}({t}_{{\\rm{D}}};\\tau ){{dt}}_{{\\rm{D}}}}.\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t15\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>We assume the SFHs of lensed sources, SFR(<em>t</em>(<em>z</em>)), follow the best-fit functional form of the observed cosmic SFH in Madau &amp; Dickinson (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib101\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib101\">2014</a>), and use the measured SFRs at <em>z</em><sub><em>S</em></sub> as normalizations</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjaad5eaeqn16\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/864/1/91/Full/apjaad5eaeqn16.gif\" alt=\"Equation (16)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&\\mathrm{SFR}(t(z))=\\mathrm{SFR}({z}_{S}){\\left(\\displaystyle \\frac{1+z(t)}{1+{z}_{S}}\\right)}^{2.7}\\,\\displaystyle \\frac{\\left[1,+,{\\left(\\tfrac{1+{z}_{S}}{2.9}\\right)}^{5.6}\\right]}{\\left[1,+,{\\left(\\tfrac{1+z(t)}{2.9}\\right)}^{5.6}\\right]}.\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t16\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>As will be shown later, the SNIa rates in this sample are primarily determined by the most recent SFRs, and therefore different assumptions on the SFHs will only introduce minor variations in the estimated SNIa rates that are negligible compared to the overall uncertainties. The delay-time distribution is assumed to be a simple power law with no minimum delay time, as suggested in Maoz et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib103\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib103\">2012</a>):</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjaad5eaeqn17\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/864/1/91/Full/apjaad5eaeqn17.gif\" alt=\"Equation (17)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{f}_{{\\rm{D}}}({t}_{{\\rm{D}}};\\tau )\\propto {t}_{{\\rm{D}}}^{-1.07}.\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t17\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>\n</p><p>The rates of CCSN and SNIa can now be estimated following Equations (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apjaad5eaeqn11\">11</a>) and (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apjaad5eaeqn15\">15</a>), and are given in Columns (9) and (10) of Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjaad5eat1\">1</a> for each individual lensed source. The rate of SNIa, <em>N</em><sub>Ia</sub>, is 0.0002\u20130.09 per year in the individual lensed galaxies, and the median <em>N</em><sub>Ia</sub> for the SLACS, S4TM, and BELLS lensed source are 0.004, 0.003, and 0.03 per year, respectively. The rate of CCSN in individual lens galaxies, <em>N</em><sub>cc</sub>, is 0.002\u20130.8 per year, and the median <em>N</em><sub>cc</sub> for the SLACS, S4TM, and BELLS lensed sources are 0.03, 0.02, and 0.2 per year. The integrated rate of SNIa across the entire lens compilation is a factor of ~8 smaller than that of CCSN. Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaad5eaf3\">3</a> shows the predicted rates of both SN types in the lensed source galaxies, as a function of the source redshifts. Because the rates are either directly proportional to (for CCSN) or determined to the leading order (for SNIa) by the SFR, <em>N</em><sub>Ia</sub> and <em>N</em><sub>cc</sub> increase with source redshift as a result of the same selection effect discussed above. This is further evident in the bimodal distributions of <em>N</em><sub>Ia</sub> and <em>N</em><sub>cc</sub> seen in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaad5eaf3\">3</a>, with the two peaks corresponding to the lower-redshift SLACS+S4TM systems and the higher-redshift BELLS systems. For the full lens compilation with 110 strong-lens systems, we expect in total 10.4\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01.1 strongly lensed CCSN events per year, and 1.23\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.12 strongly lensed SNIa events per year.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjaad5eaf3\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjaad5eaf3\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/864/1/91/Full/apjaad5eaf3_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 3.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 3.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/864/1/91/Full/apjaad5eaf3_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 3.</strong>\u00a0Distributions of the expected occurrence rates of SNIa (left) and CCSN (right) vs. source redshift for the three lens samples along with the 1D histograms shown on the side.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjaad5eaf3\" href=\"/0004-637X/864/1/91/downloadFigure/figure/apjaad5eaf3\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjaad5eaf3\" href=\"/0004-637X/864/1/91/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjaad5eaf3\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure></div></div></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjaad5eas4\" name=\"apjaad5eas4\">4.\u00a0Rates of Detectable Strongly Lensed Supernovae</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>We now proceed to estimate the occurrence rates of strongly lensed SNe in each lensed source of our lens compilation that could be detected given specific depths. We assume all the detectable SNe in the lensed galaxies are strongly lensed too. We use depths of two dedicated time-domain facilities\u2014the Zwicky Transient Facility (ZTF) and LSST\u2014as reference survey depths. The single-visit depth is 20.4 mag (5<em>\u03c3</em> for point source, <em>R</em> band) for ZTF (Bellm <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib10\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib10\">2014</a>), and 24.7 mag (5<em>\u03c3</em> for point source, <em>r</em> band) for LSST (Ivezic et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib77\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib77\">2008</a>). We thus consider \"Program1\" and \"Program2\" as two nominal monitoring programs of this lens compilation with cadences of 5 days and single-visit depths of 20.4 mag and 24.7 mag (both 5<em>\u03c3</em> for point source) in the SDSS <em>r</em> band (Doi et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib43\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib43\">2010</a>), respectively.</p><p>The detectable SN rates depend on the SN luminosity function, dust extinction, survey depth, and lensing magnification. We assume that peak absolute magnitudes in Johnson <em>B</em>-band, <em>M</em><sub><em>B</em></sub>, of different SN types are Gaussian distributed with means and standard deviations given by Richardson et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib138\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib138\">2014</a>, Table 2). The relative abundances of CCSN subtypes are taken from the same paper. For each lensed source, we convert the <em>M</em><sub><em>B</em></sub> distributions of different SN types to distributions of apparent magnitude in the <em>r</em> band. The conversion between <em>M</em><sub><em>B</em></sub> and <em>r</em>-band apparent magnitude is done based on SN template spectra with SNCosmo (Barbary <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib7\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib7\">2014</a>), a Python package that takes K correction and distance modulus into account. Specifically, the mean spectrum from Hsiao et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib74\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib74\">2007</a>) is used for SNIa, the spectrum of SN2006ep (Joubert et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib80\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib80\">2006</a>) is used for Ib, the spectrum of SN2004fe (Pugh et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib134\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib134\">2004</a>) is used for Ic, the spectrum of SN2007pg (Sako et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib144\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib144\">2018</a>) is used for IIP and IIL, and the spectrum of SN2006ix (Bassett et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib9\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib9\">2006</a>) is used for IIn. Due to the lack of observed spectra with sufficient UV coverage for IIb, we use the Ib spectrum as an approximation. As justified in the SFR estimations, we assume for each lensed source a constant extinction of <em>A</em><sub>H<em>\u03b1</em></sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.35 mag and convert <em>A</em><sub>H <em>\u03b1</em></sub> to the extinction value in the observed <em>r</em> band following a Calzetti extinction law (Calzetti et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib27\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib27\">2000</a>). For the redshift range considered in this paper (i.e., 0.2\u20131.5), the applied extinctions in the observed <em>r</em> band are in the range 0.5\u20130.8 mag.</p><p>The lensing magnification essentially extends the instrumental detection limit by a factor of 2.5 log<sub>10</sub><em>\u03bc</em>. Although the total magnifications for the extended source continuum regions have been calculated from the <em>HST</em> data, the expected magnifications of lensed SN images are very uncertain because an SN is essentially a point source, the magnification of which is extremely sensitive to its actual position in the source plane. It is also possible that the SN explosion happens away from the bright continuum region of its host galaxy, especially for SNIa. For the sake of simplicity, we adopt for all the sources a fiducial magnification factor of 5 for the most magnified SN image, which will extend the detection limit by roughly 1.75 magnitude. We note that this is a conservative assumption as the total magnifications of the three discovered strongly lensed SNe (all with four lensed images) are ~30\u2013100 (Quimby et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib136\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib136\">2014</a>; Kelly et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib84\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib84\">2015</a>; Goobar et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib61\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib61\">2017</a>). We choose not to consider magnitude fluctuations induced to individual lens systems by microlensing (e.g., Dobler &amp; Keeton <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib41\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib41\">2006</a>) as it would be beyond the scope of this paper.</p><p>In this work, we define a lensed SN as detected if its extinction-corrected peak <em>r</em>-band apparent magnitude is at least 0.7 mag brighter than the program's effective depth, defined as the single-visit depth plus 2.5 log<sub>10</sub><em>\u03bc</em>. The detected fractions of all SNe are derived from the <em>r</em>-band apparent-magnitude distributions for every single-visit depth. The detectable SN rates in each lensed source are determined by multiplying the total SN rates (<em>N</em><sub>Ia</sub> and <em>N</em><sub>cc</sub>) by these detected fractions. The requirement to be 0.7 mag brighter than the effective survey depth, used in Oguri &amp; Marshall (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib126\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib126\">2010</a>), allows detections of SN ~10 rest-frame days before peak (e.g., Firth et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib50\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib50\">2015</a>; Hoeflich et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib70\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib70\">2017</a>; He et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib68\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib68\">2018</a>; Taddia et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib172\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib172\">2018</a>). Given a cadence of 5 days, which corresponds to ~3 rest-frame days in our sources, this requirement ensures a reasonable sampling of the SN light curve, especially the early, premaximum color curve that is suggested to be insensitive to the microlensing effect and therefore crucial for accurate time-delay measurements (Goldstein et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib60\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib60\">2018</a>).</p><p>Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaad5eaf4\">4</a> shows the expected occurrence rates of detectable strongly lensed SNIa (black solid line) and CCSN (red dashed line) events as functions of the <em>r</em>-band equivalent depth. Assuming a fiducial magnification factor of 5, it suggests that in this lens compilation, Program1 could detect approximately 0.003 strongly lensed SNIa event and 0.019 strongly lensed CCSN event per year while Program2 could detect 0.49 strongly lensed SNIa event and 2.1 strongly lensed CCSN events per year. In terms of the yields in individual lens samples, the expected occurrence rates of detectable strongly lensed SNIa and CCSN in Program2 are 0.32 and 1.2 event per year for the SLACS sample, 0.12 and 0.5 event per year for the S4TM sample, and 0.05 and 0.4 event per year for the BELLS sample. We also plot the expectations with a fiducial magnification factor of 10, which are shown by the vertical, gray dotted lines. The numbers increase to 0.016 SNIa and 0.055 CCSN event per year in Program1, and 0.65 SNIa and 3.3 CCSN events per year in Program2.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjaad5eaf4\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjaad5eaf4\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/864/1/91/Full/apjaad5eaf4_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 4.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 4.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/864/1/91/Full/apjaad5eaf4_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 4.</strong>\u00a0Expected occurrence rates of detectable strongly lensed SNIa (black solid line) and CCSN (red dashed line) events as functions of the <em>r</em>-band equivalent depth. The vertical gray lines show the equivalent depths of Program1 and Program2 with fiducial magnification factors of 5 (solid line) and 10 (dotted line).</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjaad5eaf4\" href=\"/0004-637X/864/1/91/downloadFigure/figure/apjaad5eaf4\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjaad5eaf4\" href=\"/0004-637X/864/1/91/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjaad5eaf4\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>We further examine the expected occurrence rates of detectable strongly lensed SNIa and CCSN in each individual lensed source in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaad5eaf5\">5</a>. The black symbols show the rates of detectable SNIa (circle) and CCSN (square) as functions of the SN (i.e., source) redshift for Program1 assuming a fiducial magnification factor of 5, while the red symbols are the same distributions but for Program2. For Program1, the detectabilities of both SN types drop almost monotonically against the SN redshift, even though the overall SN rates are higher at higher redshifts. The reason for this is that the decrease in the fractions of detectable SNe overwhelms the increase in the overall SN rates at progressively higher redshifts given Program1's shallow detection depth. For Program2 with a deeper detection depth, the detectabilities mildly increase with redshift until about <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01 beyond which the detectability of SNIa starts dropping.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjaad5eaf5\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjaad5eaf5\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/864/1/91/Full/apjaad5eaf5_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 5.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 5.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/864/1/91/Full/apjaad5eaf5_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 5.</strong>\u00a0Expected occurrence rates of strongly lensed SNIa (circles) and CCSN (squares) events in individual lensed sources that can be detected in Program1 (black symbols) or Program2 (red symbols) as functions of the source redshift assuming a fiducial magnification factor of 5.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjaad5eaf5\" href=\"/0004-637X/864/1/91/downloadFigure/figure/apjaad5eaf5\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjaad5eaf5\" href=\"/0004-637X/864/1/91/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjaad5eaf5\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>Our results suggest that it is better to preferentially focus on lower source-redshift strong-lens systems in a survey with a limiting magnitude similar to that of Program1. A survey with a depth comparable to Program2 is generally sensitive to the entire source-redshift range considered here. To further quantify this, we check the slopes of the detectable SN rate-SN redshift relations of both types at different detection depths. We find that the slopes become positive when the detection depth reaches about 24.5 mag or brighter. This implies that the actual strategy of monitoring for strongly lensed SNe in our lens compilation should be adjusted according to the survey depth.</p></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjaad5eas5\" name=\"apjaad5eas5\">5.\u00a0Discussion</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>The biggest systematic uncertainty in our SN-rate estimation is in the conversion from [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] flux to SFR. Due to the lack of data for full calibrations on a system-by-system basis, we decided to use a subsample with simultaneous detections of H<em>\u03b1</em> emissions from the lensed sources and apply the resulting calibrations to the full sample. We note that the obtained SFR-[O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] flux relation after calibrations is almost identical to the classical relation given by Kennicutt (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib88\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib88\">1998</a>). In principle, the uncertainty of this calibration, which is found to be 50% based on current data, can be improved by carrying out additional photometric and spectroscopic observations of the lensed sources.</p><p>When deriving SNIa rates, the SFH of each individual lensed sources is assumed to follow the cosmic star formation density evolution trend given in Madau &amp; Dickinson (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib101\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib101\">2014</a>) up to an overall normalization factor. In practice, however, the SFH for each individual galaxy will not follow this cosmic evolution trend exactly, since it only represents a global average across all galaxies. We therefore investigate the uncertainty introduced to the inferred SNIa rate by the choice of SFH by computing the SNIa rate under the assumption of a constant SFR until the point of observation for each lensed source. Compared to the SNIa rates reported above, the alternative SNIa rates vary from \u221220% to +3%, with a median relative difference of \u221210% across all lensed sources. This level of variation is much smaller than the systematic uncertainty in the SNIa rate of ~50%. The integrated change in the total SNIa rate of the entire lens compilation is relatively small \u22124%. We find that the SNIa rate is primarily determined by the most recent SFH because of the rapid decline in the delay-time function. In both SFH scenarios considered, the cumulative SNIa rates have already reached 50% and 90% within the recent 0.03 and 2 Gyr. In fact, the SNIa rate scales almost linearly with the observed SFR with a slope of 4.5\u00a0<b>&#x00d7;</b>\u00a010<sup>\u22124</sup> SNe yr<sup>\u22121</sup> (<em>M</em><sub>\u2299</sub> yr<sup>\u22121</sup>)<sup>\u22121</sup>, consistent with previous findings (e.g., Sullivan et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib168\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib168\">2006</a>; Smith et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib155\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib155\">2012</a>; Graur et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib64\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib64\">2015</a>). Overall, this test suggests that different choices of the SFH would only introduce a small uncertainty in the SNIa rate, especially in the aggregate across the entire lens compilation.</p><p>Compared to a blind search, our proposed targeted search is significantly more efficient in finding strongly lensed SN events, especially ones with wide image separations. For example, 130 strongly lensed SN events with image separations larger than 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />5 will be detected by LSST after a 10-year blind search of ~20,000 square degrees' sky (Oguri &amp; Marshall <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib126\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib126\">2010</a>). Considering the ~10 square degree field of view of LSST, at least 2000 frames need to be monitored to yield these SN detections. The detection efficiency, defined as the yield of strongly lensed SN events per exposure time, of this blind search is thus ~0.006 event per year per frame. Our proposed Program2 strategy, with the same depth as LSST but targeted at known strong lenses, has a detection efficiency of ~0.025 event per year per frame, and the expected median image separation is 2''. Furthermore, none of the previous predictions for the number of strongly lensed SNe in LSST considered the effect of dust extinction, which is known to significantly reduce the number of detections. (Our detectable SN rates and detection efficiencies would increase by a factor of ~1.5 at LSST depth if the applied dust extinctions were removed.) Thousands of new strong-lens systems will be discovered in the near future from dedicated surveys (e.g., Marshall et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib106\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib106\">2009</a>; Oguri &amp; Marshall <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib126\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib126\">2010</a>; Collett <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib32\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib32\">2015</a>; McKean et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib109\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib109\">2015</a>; Diehl et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib38\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib38\">2017</a>). The application of an efficient strategy such as ours to the monitoring of these new lenses will significantly increase the yield of strongly lensed SNe.</p><p>A sample of strongly lensed SNe, especially SNIa, will be a powerful resource for cosmological studies. Time-delay cosmography with lensed QSOs is limited by the microlensing effect, which causes uncorrelated variability in the fluxes of different lensed images in an unpredictable manner and therefore complicates the time-delay measurement (e.g., Blandford &amp; Narayan <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib13\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib13\">1992</a>; Wyithe &amp; Turner <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib194\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib194\">2002</a>; Dobler &amp; Keeton <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib41\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib41\">2006</a>; Morgan et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib114\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib114\">2012</a>; Tewes et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib175\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib175\">2013</a>; More et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib112\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib112\">2017</a>; Yahalomi et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib195\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib195\">2017</a>; Tie &amp; Kochanek <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib176\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib176\">2018</a>). Compared to QSOs, for which light curves are typically stochastic with variability timescales extending to years, SNe have single-peak, more homogeneous, and standardizable light curves that develop on timescales of weeks. It is therefore much easier to determine time delays for lensed SNe than lensed QSOs in the presence of the microlensing effect. Furthermore, Goldstein et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib60\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib60\">2018</a>) recently found that accurate time-delay measurements can be obtained from early time color curves of strongly lensed SNIa, which are suggested to be almost immune to the microlensing effect. Multiply lensed SN images increase the effective number of SN events for observational study. In addition, with the aid of lensing magnification, more SNe at higher redshifts with better measured light curves can be obtained, which can enable a more extensive study of the expansion history of the universe at earlier times.</p><p>The standard-candle nature of SNe also provides extra constraining power on the mass distribution of the lens galaxy, which holds important clues to galaxy formation and evolution (e.g., Gnedin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib58\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib58\">2004</a>; Nipoti et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib122\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib122\">2004</a>; Gustafsson et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib66\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib66\">2006</a>; Romano-D\u00edaz et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib141\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib141\">2008</a>; Abadi et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib1\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib1\">2010</a>; Duffy et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib45\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib45\">2010</a>; Governato et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib63\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib63\">2010</a>; Bolton et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib14\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib14\">2012a</a>; Martizzi et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib107\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib107\">2012</a>; Dubois et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib44\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib44\">2013</a>; Velliscig et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib184\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib184\">2014</a>; Shu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib150\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib150\">2015</a>). More accurate lens-galaxy mass distributions could be obtained when the mass-sheet and source-position transformation degeneracies are broken with known lensing magnifications. However, absolute lensing magnifications are not direct observables but rather are degenerate with the intrinsic luminosities of the lensed source, which in most cases are unknown. Strongly lensed SNe with intrinsic luminosities that can be derived from lensing-independent observables are an important exception, and hence can provide better constraints on the lens-galaxy mass distributions (e.g., Witt et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib190\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib190\">1995</a>; Bolton &amp; Burles <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib15\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib15\">2003</a>; Oguri &amp; Kawano <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib125\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib125\">2003</a>; M\u00f6rtsell et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib116\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib116\">2005</a>).</p><p>Multiply imaged SNe can furthermore revolutionize the observational study of SN early and pre-explosion phases, which are driven by simple, well understood physics and thus provide crucial constraints on the progenitor properties and SN explosion mechanisms. For instance, Pritchard et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib133\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib133\">2014</a>) and Ganot et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib56\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib56\">2016</a>) highlight the importance of early UV emissions in CCSNe in determining the physical properties of the progenitors. Tornamb\u00e9 et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib177\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib177\">2018</a>) suggest that X-ray features in advance of SNIa explosions are determined by the rotation of the progenitors, which can be used to distinguish between different progenitor scenarios. Such types of observations are currently limited to a handful of unlensed SNe for which archival data or prompt follow-up observations are available (e.g., Gal-Yam et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib55\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib55\">2011</a>; Li et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib95\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib95\">2011a</a>; Nugent et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib124\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib124\">2011</a>; Dilday et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib40\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib40\">2012</a>; Cao et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib28\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib28\">2013</a>; Gal-Yam et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib54\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib54\">2014</a>; Kelly et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib83\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib83\">2014</a>; McCully et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib108\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib108\">2014</a>). The delays in the arrival times of multiple SN images, typically on scales from 1 day to 100 days, essentially replay the SN explosions multiple times. The approximate explosion times and exact locations can be predicted from the lens model after the arrival of the leading SN image. Intensive real-time monitoring of the SN site before its reappearance can be scheduled, which will greatly expand the possibilities for early and pre-explosion SN observations.</p></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjaad5eas6\" name=\"apjaad5eas6\">6.\u00a0Conclusions</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>In this paper, we propose a highly efficient strategy of finding strongly lensed SNe by monitoring known galaxy-scale strong-lens systems. We assemble a compilation of 128 galaxy\u2013galaxy strong-lens systems from the SLACS Survey, the S4TM Survey, and the BELLS Survey. All the lensed sources in this lens compilation are galaxies at redshifts of 0.2\u20131.5 with significant recent star formation. The median lensed image separation in the sample is 2''. The main findings based on this particular lens compilation are as follows.</p><ul class=\"clear-list wd-inline-list\"><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">1.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">Assuming a Salpeter IMF, the intrinsic SFRs of the lensed sources determined from the observed [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] fluxes range from 0.3 <em>M</em><sub>\u2299</sub> yr<sup>\u22121</sup> to 267 <em>M</em><sub>\u2299</sub> yr<sup>\u22121</sup>. The lensing magnification and fiber loss are corrected based on lens models from the <em>HST</em> imaging data. The median SFRs for the SLACS, S4TM, and BELLS lensed sources are 6 <em>M</em><sub>\u2299</sub> yr<sup>\u22121</sup>, 5 <em>M</em><sub>\u2299</sub> yr<sup>\u22121</sup>, and 68 <em>M</em><sub>\u2299</sub> yr<sup>\u22121</sup>, respectively. We find that the SFRs become higher at higher redshifts, which is primarily determined by the selection effect that sources at higher redshifts are biased to have higher intrinsic [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] flux given a fixed observer-frame detection limit.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">2.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">The expected overall occurrence rates of SNIa and CCSN in the lensed sources are estimated either directly from the SFRs (for CCSN) or by convolving fiducial SFHs with an SNIa delay-time distribution. For individual lensed sources, the SNIa rates are in the range of 0.0002\u20130.09 events per year, and the CCSN rates are in the range of 0.002\u20130.8 events per year. On average, the SNIa rate is a factor of ~8 lower than the CCSN rate. For the full lens compilation, we predict 1.23\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.12 strongly lensed SNIa events per year, and 10.4\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01.1 strongly lensed CCSN events per year. Mainly due to the same selection effect, the SN rates are higher at progressively higher redshifts.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">3.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">We quantify the expected occurrence rates of detectable strongly lensed SNIa and CCSN events in two nominal monitoring programs with different depths. We assume a conservative fiducial magnification factor of 5 for the most magnified SN image. Within this lens compilation, our Program1 is expected to detect approximately 0.003 strongly lensed SNIa event and 0.019 strongly lensed CCSN event per year, while our Program2 can detect 0.49 strongly lensed SNIa event and 2.1 strongly lensed CCSN events per year. This detection efficiency is significantly higher than that of a blind search.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">4.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">For this lens compilation, it is more efficient to target either higher-redshift or lower-redshift strong-lens systems depending on whether the single-visit <em>r</em>-band depth is brighter than 24.5 mag or not.</div></li></ul><p>\n</p><p>In closing, we emphasize that the fundamental principle of our proposed strategy is to focus on small targeted sky areas\u2014where known strong-lens systems are located\u2014as being more favorable sites for finding strongly lensed SNe. In the era that hundreds of new SNe (including strongly lensed SNe) are expected to be discovered every night by high-cadence, all-sky surveys such as ZTF and LSST, our proposed strategy simply helps in prompt and efficient identifications of the strong-lensing nature of the detected SNe. Meanwhile, it allows telescopes with small fields of view and limited observing time to efficiently discover strongly lensed SNe with a pencil-beam monitoring strategy. As we show in the paper, such targeted-search programs with depths comparable to that of LSST can be productive today, which is particularly worthwhile considering that LSST is scheduled to start operation in 2022 (LSST Science Collaboration et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaad5eabib99\" id=\"fnref-apjaad5eabib99\">2017</a>).</p></div> <div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>We thank the anonymous referee for comments that substantially improved the manuscript. We are grateful for the helpful discussions with Matt Auger, Peter Brown, Kyle Dawson, Mark Dickinson, Thomas Matheson, Gautham Narayan, Justin Roberts-Pierel, Steven Rodney, Hanna Sai, Lou Strolger, and Danfeng Xiang. Y.S. has been supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (NSFC; No. 11603032 and 11333008), the 973 program (No. 2015CB857003), and the Royal Society\u2014K. C. Wong International Fellowship (NF170995). S.M. acknowledges support from the NSFC (grant No. 11333003, 11390372). G.L. is supported by the NSFC (No.11673065, 11273061).</p></div></div><!-- End article full text -->\n<!-- Start Footnotes -->\n\t<!-- End Footnotes -->\t\n<!-- Start References List -->\n\n<div The rate of SNIa, <em>N</em><sub>Ia</sub>, is 0.0002\u20130.09 per year in the individual lensed galaxies, and the median <em>N</em><sub>Ia</sub> for the SLACS, S4TM, and BELLS lensed source are 0.004, 0.003, and 0.03 per year, respectively. The rate of CCSN in individual lens galaxies, <em>N</em><sub>cc</sub>, is 0.002\u20130.8 per year, and the median <em>N</em><sub>cc</sub> for the SLACS, S4TM, and BELLS lensed sources are 0.03, 0.02, and 0.2 per year. The integrated rate of SNIa across the entire lens compilation is a factor of ~8 smaller than that of CCSN. Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaad5eaf3\">3</a> shows the predicted rates of both SN types in the lensed source galaxies, as a function of the source redshifts. Because the rates are either directly proportional to (for CCSN) or determined to the leading order (for SNIa) by the SFR, <em>N</em><sub>Ia</sub> and <em>N</em><sub>cc</sub> increase with source redshift as a result of the same selection effect discussed above. This is further evident in the bimodal distributions of <em>N</em><sub>Ia</sub> and <em>N</em><sub>cc</sub> seen in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaad5eaf3\">3</a>, with the two peaks corresponding to the lower-redshift SLACS+S4TM systems and the higher-redshift BELLS systems. For the full lens compilation with 110 strong-lens systems, we expect in total 10.4\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01.1 strongly lensed CCSN events per year, and 1.23\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.12 strongly lensed SNIa events per year."}, "Action": "Scanned all subtables", "Status": "Complete"}}, "Paper text": "<!DOCTYPE html>\n<html lang=\"en\">\n\t<head>\n\t\t<meta http-equiv=\"X-UA-Compatible\" <main role=\"main\">\n        <!-- Secondary header starts -->\n<div class=\"secondary-header cf\" id=\"wd-secondary-header\">\n    <!-- Branded journal header starts -->\n<div class=\"big-branded\">\n\n    <div class=\"publication-name\" id=\"wd-pub-name\">\n\t<div class=\"publication-title\" itemprop=\"name\" itemid=\"periodical\">\n\t\t\t\t<!-- Journal image link tile starts -->\n<!-- Logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"/journal/0004-637X\" itemprop=\"url\">\n    <img src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/8febf88b-d09c-11e5-b0b6-759f86a2008e/apj-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Astrophysical Journal\">\n</a>\n<!-- Logo tile ends -->\n<!-- Journal image link tile ends -->\n</div>\n\t\t</div>\n    <div class=\"partner-logos m-hide\" id=\"wd-partner-logos\">\n            <div class=\"partner-logo-alignment\">\n                <!-- Partner logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"\" class=\"overlay-launch\">\n    <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/8a2230b8-d09c-11e5-b0b6-759f86a2008e/aas-2018.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The American Astronomical Society, find out more\">\n</a>\n<span class=\"overlay-set\">\n    <div class=\"tint-screen\"></div>\n    <div class=\"overlay-panel\">\n        <a title=\"Close\"  class=\"close-icon close-overlay\" tabindex=\"0\" role=\"button\" aria-describedby=\"close-icon-description\"><span class=\"icon-close\"></span></a>\n        <p id=\"close-icon-description\" class=\"offscreen-hidden\">Click here to close this overlay, or press the \"Escape\" key on your keyboard.</p>\n        <div class=\"overlay-img\">\n            <a href=\"\">\n                <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/8a2230b8-d09c-11e5-b0b6-759f86a2008e/aas-2018.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The American Astronomical Society, find out more\">\n            </a>\n        </div>\n        <div class=\"overlay-text\">\n            <p>The American Astronomical Society (AAS), established in 1899 and based in Washington, DC, is the major organization of professional astronomers in North America. Its membership of about 7,000 individuals also includes physicists, mathematicians, geologists, engineers, and others whose research and educational interests lie within the broad spectrum of subjects comprising contemporary astronomy. The mission of the AAS is to enhance and share humanity's scientific understanding of the universe.</p> <p><a href=\"https://aas.org/\">https://aas.org/</a></div>\n        <p class=\"ta-c mt-1 mb-2\"><a href=\"\"></a></p>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- Partner logo tile ends -->\n\n<!-- Partner logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"\" class=\"overlay-launch\">\n    <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/7ebd1b32-0439-11e9-b401-cfe9679c40e3/iop-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Institute of Physics, find out more\">\n</a>\n<span class=\"overlay-set\">\n    <div class=\"tint-screen\"></div>\n    <div class=\"overlay-panel\">\n        <a title=\"Close\"  class=\"close-icon close-overlay\" tabindex=\"0\" role=\"button\" aria-describedby=\"close-icon-description\"><span class=\"icon-close\"></span></a>\n        <p id=\"close-icon-description\" class=\"offscreen-hidden\">Click here to close this overlay, or press the \"Escape\" key on your keyboard.</p>\n        <div class=\"overlay-img\">\n            <a href=\"\">\n                <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/7ebd1b32-0439-11e9-b401-cfe9679c40e3/iop-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Institute of Physics, find out more\">\n            </a>\n        </div>\n        <div class=\"overlay-text\">\n            <p>The Institute of Physics (IOP) is a leading scientific society promoting physics and bringing physicists together for the benefit of all. It has a worldwide membership of around 50 000 comprising physicists from all sectors, as well as those with an interest in physics. It works to advance physics research, application and education; and engages with policy makers and the public to develop awareness and understanding of physics. Its publishing company, IOP Publishing, is a world leader in professional scientific communications.</p> <p><a href=\"https://www.iop.org\">https://www.iop.org</a></p></div>\n        <p class=\"ta-c mt-1 mb-2\"><a href=\"\"></a></p>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- Partner logo tile ends -->\n\n<p></p>\n                </div>\n        </div>\n    </div>\n<!-- Branded journal header ends -->\n</div> <!-- end secondary-header -->\n<!-- Secondary header ends --><div class=\"da1-da2\" itemscope=\"\" itemtype=\"http://schema.org/ScholarlyArticle\" id=\"page-content\">\n            <div class=\"da1 ta1 article-head\">\n                <!-- Start Eyebrow block, containing Surtitle and Labels -->\n<div class=\"eyebrow\">\n\t<!-- Start Collection Labels -->\n    <!-- End Collection Labels --> </div>\n<!-- End Eyebrow block -->\n\n<h1 itemprop=\"headline\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-title\">Prediction of Supernova Rates in Known Galaxy\u2013Galaxy Strong-lens Systems</h1>\n\n<p class=\"mb-0\">\n\t<span data-authors=\"\">\n\t\t<span itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Person\" itemprop=\"author\" class=\"nowrap\"><span itemprop=\"name\">Yiping Shu</span><sup>1,2,7</sup></span>, <span itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Person\" itemprop=\"author\" class=\"nowrap\"><span itemprop=\"name\">Adam S. Bolton</span><sup>3</sup></span>, <span itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Person\" itemprop=\"author\" class=\"nowrap\"><span itemprop=\"name\">Shude Mao</span><sup>4,5,6</sup></span>, <span itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Person\" itemprop=\"author\" class=\"nowrap\"><span itemprop=\"name\">Xi Kang</span><sup>1</sup></span>, <span itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Person\" itemprop=\"author\" class=\"nowrap\"><span itemprop=\"name\">Guoliang Li</span><sup>1</sup></span>, and <span itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Person\" itemprop=\"author\" class=\"nowrap\"><span itemprop=\"name\">Monika Soraisam</span><sup>3</sup></span></span>\n</p>\n\n<p class=\"small\" itemprop=\"isPartOf\" itemscope=\"\" itemtype=\"http://schema.org/PublicationIssue\">\n\t<!--Article Breadcrumb Tile Start-->\n<span class=\"wd-jnl-art-pub-date\">Published 2018 September 4</span> &bull; <!-- Start Copyright-->\n    <span itemprop=\"copyrightHolder\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-copyright\">\n       \t  \u00a9 2018. This includes author emails, affiliations, article published date, doi etc. -->\n\t<div class=\"reveal-container reveal-closed reveal-plus-icon bdt-1 wd-jnl-art-article-info-wrapper\">\n      \t<div class=\"replica-h3 mt-0\">\n        \t<a id=\"wd-article-info-accordion\" href=\"#\" class=\"reveal-trigger\" data-reveal-label-alt=\"Hide article information\">Article information</a>\n      \t</div>\n      \t<div class=\"reveal-content\">\n        \t<div class=\"article-meta\">\n          \t\t<!-- Start Authors --><div class=\"wd-jnl-art-email-addresses\"><div class=\"replica-h4\">Author e-mails</div><p class=\"mb-0\"><a href=\"mailto:yiping.shu@pmo.ac.cn\" title=\"Send mail to yiping.shu@pmo.ac.cn\">yiping.shu@pmo.ac.cn</a></p><p class=\"mb-0\"><a href=\"mailto:bolton@noao.edu\" title=\"Send mail to bolton@noao.edu\">bolton@noao.edu</a></p></div><!-- End Authors --><!-- Start Affiliations --><div class=\"wd-jnl-art-author-affiliations\"><div class=\"replica-h4\">Author affiliations</div><p class=\"mb-05\"><sup>1</sup>  Purple Mountain Observatory, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 2 West Beijing Road, Nanjing 210008, People's Republic of China</p><p class=\"mb-05\"><sup>2</sup>  Institute of Astronomy, University of Cambridge, Madingley Road, Cambridge CB3 0HA, UK</p><p class=\"mb-05\"><sup>3</sup>  National Optical Astronomy Observatory, 950 N. Cherry Avenue, Tucson, AZ 85719, USA</p><p class=\"mb-05\"><sup>4</sup>  Physics Department and Tsinghua Centre for Astrophysics, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, People's Republic of China</p><p class=\"mb-05\"><sup>5</sup>  National Astronomical Observatories, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 20A Datun Road, Chaoyang District, Beijing 100012, People's Republic of China</p><p class=\"mb-05\"><sup>6</sup>  Jodrell Bank Centre for Astrophysics, School of Physics and Astronomy, The University of Manchester, Oxford Road, Manchester M13 9PL, UK</p><p class=\"mb-05\"><sup>7</sup> Royal Society\u2014K.C. Wong International Fellow.</p></div><!-- End Affiliations --><!-- Start Dates -->\n<div class=\"col-no-break wd-jnl-art-dates\">\n        <div class=\"replica-h4\">Dates</div>\n        <p>\n            \n                Received <span itemprop=\"dateReceived\">2018 January 22</span><br />\n            \n                Accepted <span itemprop=\"dateAccepted\">2018 July 23</span><br />\n            \n                    Published <span itemprop=\"datePublished\">2018 September 4</span><br />\n                </p>\n    </div>\n<!-- End Dates -->\n\n<!-- Start Crossmark -->\n\t\t\t\t<p class=\"wd-jnl-art-crossmark\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<a target=\"_blank\" href=\"http://crossmark.crossref.org/dialog/?doi=10.3847/1538-4357/aad5ea&domain=pdf\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<img -->\n\n\t\t\t\t<!-- Start Peer Review Metrics -->\n<!-- End Peer Review Metrics -->\n\n<!--  Start Citation -->\n                    <!--  End Citation -->\n\t\t\t\t\n\t\t\t\t<!-- Start DOI -->\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"col-no-break wd-jnl-art-doi\">\n\t\t\t\t\t<div class=\"replica-h4\">\n\t\t\t\t\t<abbr title=\"digital object identifier\">DOI</abbr>\n\t\t\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t\t\t\t<p><a itemprop=\"sameAs\" href=\"https://doi.org/10.3847/1538-4357/aad5ea\">https://doi.org/10.3847/1538-4357/aad5ea</a></p>\n\t\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t\t\t<!-- End DOI -->\n\t\t\t\t\n\t\t\t\t<!-- Start Accepted manuscript Link -->\n<!-- End Accepted manuscript Link -->\n<!-- Start Annotations -->\n <!-- End Annotations --><div class=\"col-no-break wd-jnl-aas-keywords\">\n\t\t<div class=\"replica-h4\">Keywords</div>\n\t\t<p><a href=\"/searchaaskeyword?source=aas&amp;type=kwd_group&amp;code=11%2F48&amp;code_desc=cosmology%3A+observations\">cosmology: observations</a>; <a href=\"/searchaaskeyword?source=aas&amp;type=kwd_group&amp;code=2%2F46&amp;code_desc=gravitational+lensing%3A+strong\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>; <a href=\"/searchaaskeyword?source=aas&amp;type=kwd_group&amp;code=8%2F52&amp;code_desc=supernovae%3A+general\">supernovae: general</a></p>\n\t</div>\n<!-- Start Reprint Link -->\n\t<!-- End Reprint Link --><!-- Start Journal RSS feed -->\n                    <div class=\"jnl-notifications-wrapper jnl-notifications-wrapper--rss\">\n                        <a class=\"wd-jnl-rss\" href=\"/journal/rss/0004-637X\"><span\n                                class=\"icon-feed icon-feed--jhp\"></span>Journal RSS</a>\n                    </div>\n\t\t\t\t\t<!-- End Journal RSS feed -->\n\t\t\t\t\t<!-- Start Email Alert -->\n    <!-- Start Email Alert -->\n        <div class=\"jnl-notifications-wrapper\">\n            <a class=\"wd-jnl-email-alert loginRequired\"\n class=\"overlay-set\" id=\"corridor-alerts-overlay\">\n    <div class=\"tint-screen\"></div>\n    <div class=\"overlay-panel two-columns\">\n        <div id=\"innerContainer\">\n            <a
